Biography

Abstract

Johannes Diderik van der Waals was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1910 "for his work on the equation of state for gases and liquids." Throughout the majority of his career, he held a position at the University of Amsterdam, where he was the first Professor of Physics.

Physicist.

November 23, 1837Birth, Leiden (Netherlands).

1864Teacher at a secondary school, Deventer (Netherlands).

1865Obtained teaching certificates in mathematics and physics, University of Leiden (Rijksuniversiteit te Leiden), Leiden (Netherlands).

1866Teacher and Director at a secondary school, Hague (Netherlands).

1873Obtained PhD in Physics, University of Leiden (Rijksuniversiteit te Leiden), Leiden (Netherlands).

1875Member, Royal Netherlands Academy of Sciences (Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen).

1876Professor of Physics, University of Amsterdam (Universiteit van Amsterdam), Amsterdam (Netherlands).

1896 – 1912Secretary, Royal Netherlands Academy of Sciences (Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen).

1910Awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics "for his work on the equation of state for gases and liquids".

March 8, 1923Death, Amsterdam (Netherlands).
